title: It's time we manned up against the liberal war on language
text:
"Diabetes on a plate" should not be analysed so seriously

In recent times, something extraordinary has happened to me: I’ve started to feel sorry for Paul Hollywood. Having had one of the most drawn-out celebrity break-ups of all time, he can’t seem to do anything without the media telling him off.

This week’s controversy was about sugar glazed Chelsea buns. On The Great British Bake Off he said some of them looked like “diabetes on a plate”. After being accused of insulting people with the health condition on social media, he apologised quickly.

Of course, for anyone with diabetes - particularly type 1, which isn’t related to weight - comments around it can be irritating. But Hollywood was...
